The story is...Well it can't be more Epic in scope than that, trust me on this. The leveling is fast and you can expect to reach about 34th level at the end of the 2nd module with the 3rd taking you to the full 40th.

posts.content:
So, i went on and re-played the first module in the series with a 15th level character this time one of my own. Nothing special just a pure fighter with no special equipment, but its important to start with at least a +3 weapon (the pre-gens had +4's) and in my opinion a good AC of at least 35. Most important feats are in order: Knockdown, Power-attack & Expertise, as usual really. Knockdown will prove very useful throughout the series, even the simple version of it, so you better have it if you play a melee character. A ranged weapon (doesn't have to be something special, a plain composite +3 bow or the equivalent will suffice) will prove useful as well to seperate big mobs from their leaders.

I have to say the module's creator did a pretty good job with the rewards that you get from your fallen opponents and in other cases the items that are crafted for you by certain individuals. At the start it might seem that this is a high magic "maunty haul" type of module but it isn't to my big surprise, and the overall magic level is well below the HoTU's levels, which i find it extreme and tends to destroy the sense of challenge. Almost all of the named enemies have their own unique items that you get to loot after you defeat them and they cover a wide variety of arms & armour with the occasional finds for mages & clerics. Some of you will be happy to hear that special care has been taken so that Monks do not feel under-equipped, as there is a plethora of magic items to find for them, and that is even more apparent in the sequels. The creator of the module also appears to have a knack for the eastern-themed cultures so samurai's and katana's lovers won't regret it for sure!

Another thing that doesn't seem much in the beginning is the story & the background in general. You start as a mercenary that travels to the lowly town of Twin-Summits but your caravan get attacked en-route and your team are the only survivors of that attack (the module most of the time, assumes you are a team in conversations). With your friend & mentor killed and without an alternative to go in the midst of winter, you set on an adventure to find the murderers and take revenge. Right away you notice though that things aren't so simple and greater evils lurks behind, namely the two foreign dragons that took an interest on Twin-Summits some time ago because of its mithril mines. There is also the rumour that the ruins of an ancient elven civilization lies underneath the town... Can you find the connection between the two? Who is really Lord Shin and what are his connections with the blue dragon Shael and the Divine? Most importantly who is that mysterious mage locked aways by his own volition in the dungeons of the militia's HQ?

It's my fault i didn't explained this better, let's do this properly now...

Normally you are right Stag, that since you have a newer version of the CEP (2.60) you do not need an older one. That is correct, except from the fact that this is true from version 2.00 and after. For the old modules the authors used the 1.XX versions of CEP that the newer stuff won't cover. This is the case with both Diablo-Lord of Terror & MTS Trilogy. The authors used 1.XX CEP to build their modules (the only one available at the time) so you need the installer for 1.XX CEP. Now this does not interfare with any newer versions of CEP 2.XX and later. It is installed seperately and works that way.

Then you have to use a CEP installer for 1.XX version, there are two installers like this. The first one is this: https://neverwintervault.org/project/nw ... -installer
But with this version you also need to download a little seperate fix that updates the cloaks to 1.69 patch, the installer you see covers everything but up to the 1.68 version of the game.

The version i linked to you in the previous post however it is already patched to 1.69 and it is also recommended from the module's page. It is supposed to be the most recent version for ALL the old CEP modules. Now, take notice that i do not use that version since i have already installed the old one (with the fix applied) and i also use other utilities like Cloak Converter and so on, but this is not essential for you and i don't wantr to confuse you with additional stuff (one step at a time). That is why i linked the newer CEP installer and it should work like a charm.

I hope that covers up everything, have fun ;)

Downloading a trainer module is nothing different than downloading any other module from NWN Vault.

posts.author: Mirnaia
posts.content:
After a stressful period of work and being generally down, I decided to take a break from WoG and try the OC, or as Hip calls it, the Plague Campaign, followed by the MTS trilogy. I decided to take the elven Princess Süel Nightingale, a magical master along, to learn the build in a less stressful environment than Greyhawk. The magical master starts as a 15 level cleric, getting all the good buffs at their cap (except Shield of Faith at +4), eventually gets a full wizard spellbook, EMA and EW at 39, and is still a 10 APR monk, taking monk levels at 17 and 40 (or 37, your choice).

It was only my second time through the OC, and I found it exceptionally boring and tedious. I swear I did more damage to containers than to enemies. Who the hell designed this loot system and thought this is what players are going to find fun? Very long story short, I slogged through it (solo), there were the occasional moments of fun and depth. Since the build has an XP penalty from level 17 on, I waited on taking my final level until after Morag, and went into that module as a Cleric 15 / Monk 1 / Illusionist 1. I saw from Empyre's screenshots that non-XP-penalty characters earn over a million points over the campaign, so I should be able to hit 40. Also, whenever I'm lower level I get more XP, so in reality the penalty is less than the nominal 20%.

After the OC, I was wondering how the build would fare in MTS's high magic world. On the plus side, it is Dex-based with max APR, which is great for high magic, the setting allows for maxing many abilities which is sorely needed here (Dex, Int/Wis, Con are the most important ones in that order) and of course it's an incredibly versatile character. However, because of the very high enhancement bonuses, extra feats, and loads of immunities that are normally found on high magic gear, I will eventually lose a lot of the edge given by all the buffs at my disposal. Turns out I shouldn't have worried.

And I'm finding MTS FUN. I generally like when the hack and slash parts and the decision-making parts are separated, and MTS nails that perfectly. Especially in a game where the clock keeps on ticking during conversations and your buffs keep running out because you struck up a friendly conversation. It is of personal preference, but I love the level design, it reminds me of the Hell Revealed maps in Doom.

I ended up doing quite a bit of the first module backwards. I did the wolf-fox thing, then went down to the sewers, and went all the way down and then up to the lab and then down Zael's mountain. Next was Khor, and again I found myself in his domain after I broke into his sanctuary in town. And then I did all the rest. I handed in the heads to the mayor, oopsie, and did not take the deal with the devil. Finished at level 26, Cleric 15 / Monk 1 / Wizard 10. The build devastated the module, killing Zael without breaking a sweat at level 20, even though I used my GMW'd OC kamas throughout, because the first one in MTS dropped from the final boss.

And thus the War of the Fallen began, and it was mostly another slaughterfest. The monster density in the riverside and surrounding areas is insane, but I guess they are there to help underleveled people catch up. I could not find a way to avoid the first volley by the Jacks (didn't have level 8 or 9 wizard spells at that point), so there was always the 5% chance of petrification. Went with Shin and helped the Wandering God for an insane kama. Since the cleric buffs are easily dispellable, as are the mage ones at those levels, the dragons at the end were annoying until I figured out that they stand no chance even when I'm unbuffed. The lady at the end was the only monster who could reliably hit me, but that got taken care of quickly with a Bigby 5. Finished at level 35, Cleric 15 / Monk 1 / Wizard 19.

Ah, yes. You'll first need to get to the place where you can sell that humongous amount of gear you've gathered. Once you see Charon, you'll know you're in the right area, and he'll sail you there. Don't worry if you haven't finished everything before travelling, you can come back, vastly wealthy and unburdened by sheets and sheets and bags and bags of holding bursting with stuff. Each trader on the island will offer a different price for your stuff, so play smart. They also have a finite sum of money, and you can easily drain them all of funds. Worry not, Shin has a friendly trading angel when you get to his place - and you'll get the info for where to find it from the chap in the central tower on the island. The monk who gives you the Susymog quest is also there.

My strategy for Part 2 is basically to go clockwise from when I exit the very first screen (sort of 7 o'clock to 12), and clear everything on that side until getting to the Charon screen (the huge river - the Styx - looming in the distance of the screen should be a bit of a giveaway as well). Then I re-stock and sell stuff, get Charon to take me back, and go from 12 to 5 o'clock. Don't miss any screens and secret doors en route in both directions! Then back to the island and sell some more, if they still have any coin left, or go straight to see Shin (I wouldn't advise his brother - you'll be seeing him eventually anyway, but if you've gone for evil, he's your man - but he has no shop). Shin will certainly have a quest for you.
